bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to John J. Moran, May 14, 1929

div1.p: Kean describes to Moran the attempts made to expand the list of people qualified for yellow fever pensions, and explains how the criteria were set.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to John J. Moran, May 14, 1929

14 May, 1929.
Mr. John J. Moran,
Ave. Washington Nos. 36-40
Havana, Cuba.
My dear Mr. Moran:
div1.p:
I appreciate very much the courtesy and good will in your
letter of May 9th. Everything connected with the work of the Reed
Board is of so much interest to me that I deserve little credit for
my efforts to spread a knowledge of it, or to get rewards for the men who
made it possible. You are, however, quite mistaken if you think that
I am through with it. General Ireland sends everything that comes to
his office down to me for reply or comment, and now that the papers have
all published the Roll of Honor, every fellow that saw a case of yellow
fever, or looked over the back fence of Camp Lazear wants to get in on it.
Very naturally I find the widows especially hard to convince that their
husbands are not heroes of the purest brand. Of course there are a number
of very fine fellows who did wonderful work in connection with the care
of yellow fever cases, but a line has to be drawn somewhere, and it was
drawn at those Americans who actually took part in the experiments of the
Reed Board. The experiments of Dr. Guiteras at Las Animas which did not
seem to get anywhere, but which cost three lives, have not been included.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J. R. KEAN,
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retd., JRK/F
